overview_of_class:
Roman Catholicism was one of?if not the?major force in shaping modern sexualities, as irritant, fantasy, boundary, and more. From whatever perspective?aesthetics, theology and ritual, penitential practice and disciplines, of the control of bodies and desires, the construction of sexual identities over time, missionaries and the extension of Catholic sexuality beyond Europe and North America?the Catholic imaginary is central to the history of modern sexuality. In the era after the Council of Trent in 1545, when the history of modern Catholicism begins, there was a determined effort within the Church to discipline Catholics around the world into obedience and submission to Roman rules and rubrics. Sexuality was mobilized in different ways as a site of disciplinary action and of resistance in this project, within Catholicism and at the border between Catholicism and other cultures.

Too often in the past scholars have approached the question of Catholicism and sexuality in terms of the church's explicit ethical teachings. While this is an important topic, it is not the direction taken by this course.

Instead the course is guided by five key positions:
(1) that the influence of Catholicism on modern sexuality was global in its reach, not only in its efforts to extirpate "pagan" sexual practices around the world, but also as a node for the circulation of sexual information and desires;
2) that as the necessary other of post-Reformation modernity, Catholicism became the object of sexual curiosity and fantasy, abetting resistance among non-Catholics to modern sexual regimes and at the same time serving sexual rebels as a syllabus of alternative possibilities;
3) Catholicism offered a venue for the queering of modern sexualities, in convents, rectories, religious orders of men and women;
4) Catholic sexual disciplines and the exercise of Catholic power over bodies was, on the one hand, coercive and destructive, and on the other, generative;
5) Catholic history is characterized by the simultaneity of the unsimultaneous, so that studying modern Catholic sexual history entails attending to the longue durée of practice and ideas.



Within this framework, the course will be organized as a series of case studies; there will be primary and secondary readings.
